post.content:
A fun (or better: frightening) thing about my mastodon series about key new features in #systemd258 is that even though I am currently at episode 39 already, the list of further features I want to cover *still* contains 17 items. Yikes.

We really need to get better at release engineering I guess, and release more frequently and in smaller steps. But that is easily said, but very hard to do.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content: @pid_eins how's the beta testing program on the main branch? i feel like that's one of the most important things to making sure it's safe to release at any time: is it easy for people to help out and test and is there a carrot for doing it?

fields.name: GitHub
fields.value: https://github.com/NekkoDroid

fields.name: Twitch
fields.value: https://twitch.tv/NekkoDroid

replies.content:
@pid_eins There's a lot of features, I can hardly follow the series. :)

As far as I can see, mapping devices (eg. /dev/dri) into a container is still pretty hard due to userns. Is systemd-nsresourced supposed to make that easier, or is there already a way to do that (and it's only me who is unable to find it)?

replies.content: @pid_eins I don't think releasing often is going to change anything about the number of new features threads you do per unit of time... 😂

lennart_followups.content: @hruske the kernel driver model knows no concept of namespacing devices, hence sharing hw devices into containers is always a fricking mess. But that's not something we could fix in userspace, it's simply a limitation of the Linux kernel.

all_descendants.content: @hruske the kernel driver model knows no concept of namespacing devices, hence sharing hw devices into containers is always a fricking mess. But that's not something we could fix in userspace, it's simply a limitation of the Linux kernel.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins It is a mess, yes.

I have managed to manually "share" a GPU into a user-mode LXC container with a custom gidmap, basically stitching together a group idmap to map the video and render groups from host into container, but kept the other ids within the user's subgid space.

Not great, but I could then have hw transcoding and not pollute my host OS with vendor software, but also (mostly) have separate user namespace.

account.note: Human. Born into 344ppm. Most interested in the energy stuff. (Physics, not some made up things.)

fields.name: Blog
fields.value: https://zejn.net/b/

fields.name: Twitter
fields.value: https://twitter.com/hruske

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins This is how it looks in lxc config:

# map groups in container to make video acceleration work
# numbers are guest host count
# render: 108 container -> 106 host
# video: 44 container -> 44 host
lxc.idmap = g 0 558752 44
lxc.idmap = g 44 44 1
lxc.idmap = g 45 558797 63
lxc.idmap = g 108 106 1
lxc.idmap = g 109 558861 65427

Just to confirm: punching "holes" in uidmap like this is currently not possible with nspawn, right?
